questions.text: The procedure shown in the image below is being performed on a 35-year-old male patient, who presented with complaints of dysphagia, regurgitation, and chest pain. His barium swallow showed a bird’s beak appearance near the gastroesophageal junction. What is the procedure performed on this patient known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

POEM

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of achalasia cardia, and the procedure shown above is called peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM).
Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder caused due to the degeneration of neurons in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), thereby causing a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction.

The patients present with a triad of dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. The dysphagia initially begins with liquid foods and then progresses to solid foods, halitosis is present due to the accumulation of food. Patients may develop pneumonia, lung abscess, etc. at a later stage.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with verrucous carcinoma around the glans of the penis. Examination reveals that the inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Partial penectomy.

The most appropriate management for this patient with verrucous carcinoma around the glans of the penis is partial penectomy.
Carcinoma of the penis is commonly a squamous cell carcinoma. It arises from the skin of the glans penis or the prepuce. The lesion can be flat or warty in appearance.

T1-confined to the skin

T2-invades the corpus spongiosum or cavernosum.

T3-invades the urethra

T4-invades adjacent structures.

The first lymph node to be involved is the superficial inguinal lymph node and thus, the sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is helpful for evaluating the spread of penile cancer.

questions.text: A CECT abdomen done to evaluate an elderly man with intermittent flank pain is shown below. Which of the following will be the most common site for secondary metastasis in patients with this tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lungs

The history and CECT mentioned in the above scenario are consistent with a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma. The most common site for secondary metastasis in RCC is the lungs, where they form secondaries commonly known as cannonball secondaries.
The tumor is prone to extend into the renal vein and reach the lungs via circulation. RCC also metastasizes to the bone, lymph nodes, liver, adrenal glands, and brain.

Para-aortic nodes are the first draining lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate presents with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting. An erect X-ray of the abdomen is done and shown below. The neonate is taken up for surgery and an apple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is seen. Which type of ileal atresia has this feature?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Type 3

The given image showing a triple bubble appearance and associated finding of apple-peel bowel with loss of dorsal mesentery is a feature of type 3 ileal atresia.

Small bowel atresias present with intestinal obstruction soon after birth. Bilious vomiting is the dominant feature in jejunal atresia whereas abdominal distension is more with ileal atresia.

Plain abdominal radiographs show a variable number of dilated loops of bowel and fluid levels according to the level of obstruction.

choices.text: It is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra
Circumcision should be done to remove the excess skin
It does not cause urinary obstruction
Ventral chordee is a common association

questions.text: A newborn was found to have a following anomaly of the penile urethra while being examined by a pediatrician. Identify the incorrect statement regarding the condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Circumcision should be done to remove the excess skin

The image showing a newborn having a urethral meatus that opens on the underside of the penis is indicative of hypospadias. Circumcision should not be done in hypospadias as the foreskin will be used for surgical reconstruction.

choices.text: All patients with this condition should be evaluated for psychiatric conditions
Aperistalsis in the oesophageal body is the characteristic feature
Calcium channel blockers may be tried in mildly symptomatic patients
This condition is seen most often in female patients

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes to the clinic with difficulty swallowing food and liquids for the last two months. She also complains of a sensation of food getting stuck in her throat. She has had an intermittent burning sensation in her throat and chest during the last month. Further evaluation with barium swallow shows the findings below. Which of the following is false about her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aperistalsis in the oesophageal body is the characteristic feature

The above clinical picture and barium swallow showing a corkscrew appearance are characteristic of a diffuse esophageal spasm (DES). Aperistalsis of the oesophageal body is a characteristic finding in achalasia cardia, not DES.

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm – It is a poorly understood hypermotility disorder of the esophagus seen more commonly in women. Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain which is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. Esophageal contractions are repetitive, simultaneous, and of high amplitude. However, in between the contractions, peristalsis remains normal. This condition is seen most often in female patients

choices.text: Decompression of cyst improves renal function

questions.text: A known hypertensive presented with intermittent left-sided flank pain. His brother passed away two years ago due to a ruptured berry aneurysm. CT abdomen done is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Decompression of cyst improves renal function

The given scenario with CT showing multiple cysts in the kidneys and liver points to a diagnosis of adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). In such patients, decompression or deroofing of the cysts (Rovsing’s procedure) cannot restore normal renal function.

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1 (chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4).
The disease does not usually manifest before 30 years of age, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed. The progression of the disease is faster in males.

questions.text: You notice the following test is being performed by your senior on a 30-year-old patient having an Alvarado score of 7. The patient complained of pain in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen on performing the test. What is the name given to this clinical sign?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Psoas sign

The name given to this clinical sign is the Psoas sign.

The Alvarado score is a clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. A score of 7, as seen in this patient, suggests probable appendicitis.

Various clinical signs have been described which are used in the diagnosis of appendicitis. Abdominal pain with hyperextension of the right hip is known as the Psoas sign. This is because of psoas muscle spasm, due to the inflamed appendix being in contact with this muscle. The patient often lies in a posture with the right hip flexed for pain relief.

questions.text: A patient with rectal prolapse underwent surgery. The postoperative image is given below. Identify the procedure.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Thiersch wiring

The postoperative image shows a purse-string suture which is suggestive of Thiersch wiring for rectal prolapse.

In Thiersch’s wiring, a steel wire or a silastic/nylon tape is placed around the anal canal. It is rarely done now due to post-operative problems like chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

questions.text: A delayed intravenous urogram of a patient is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Pelviureteric junction obstruction

The delayed intravenous urogram (IVU) of the patient showing hydronephrosis with an absence of contrast in the ureter makes the likely diagnosis a pelviureteric junction obstruction.

Pelviureteric Junction obstruction is the commonest type of urinary obstruction in childhood, but can also be seen in young adults. It is usually caused by intrinsic stenosis. It manifests as abdominal flank or back pain, and hematuria. In newborns, a renal mass is palpable.

questions.text: What is the appropriate age at which corrective surgery should be done for the defect shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

6-18 months

The image shows penoscrotal hypospadias. Operations for hypospadias are routinely performed when the patient is between 6 and 18 months of age. The infant has good tolerance to surgery by the age of 6 months. The child is well aware of his genitalia and will be toilet trained by the age of 18 months

questions.text: The instrument shown below will be least useful for examining patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Acute anal fissure

The given image shows a proctoscope. It is not used for examining patients with anal fissures.

Due to pain, digital rectal examination and anoscopy are not performed immediately in an acute anal fissure. It is reserved for later when the symptoms resolve or the patient is in the operating room.

choices.text: Causes the most common type of gastritis
Associated with causation of gastric MALToma
Considered by WHO as class I carcinogen

questions.text: A biopsy was obtained from a patient with chronic peptic ulcer disease. The pathological slide is given below. Identify the false statement regarding the causative agent of this condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Causes hypogastrinemia

The given slide shows the Gl mucosa, stained with Warthin-Starry silver stain, infected with Helicobacter pylori. H. pylori cause hypergastrinemia.

The ammonia released by H. pylori acts on the antral G-cells and releases gastrin. This is responsible for hypergastrinemia in these patients resulting in type B gastritis (the most common type of gastritis).

Urea breath test and antibodies to H. pylori help us with diagnosis. The gold standard investigation for H. pylori is a tissue biopsy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the surgery OPD with epigastric pain, bloating, cough, and acid reflux. His symptoms subside slightly on taking antacids. He is being worked up for peptic ulcer disease. He has a gastric ulcer in the region of the stomach marked in the image below. What will be the type of ulcer in this case according to the Modified Johnson anatomical classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Type IV

The above image shows type IV of the modified johnson anatomical classification of gastric ulcer. It is seen high along the lesser curvature of the stomach and is not related to increased gastric acid levels.

questions.text: Which investigation is not necessary for the following condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

24-h pH monitoring

The given barium swallow shows a bird beak appearance and is suggestive of achalasia cardia. 24-h pH monitoring is not necessary for achalasia cardia. It is used in the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).

Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder. It is characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation in response to swallowing. This is due to the loss of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach’s) plexus. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction.

choices.text: Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases
Caused by overexpression of TNF alpha

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, loss of appetite, and loss of weight. On examination, the patient had peripheral edema and ascites. Laboratory studies showed decreased serum albumin but normal serum levels of transaminases and gastrin. Upper GI endoscopy showed the following appearance of the stomach. Which of the following is true about the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases

The given clinical scenario and the image showing the presence of hypertrophied gastric mucosal folds are characteristic of Menetrier’s disease. Gastrectomy is the treatment of choice in severe cases of Menetrier’s disease.

Menetrier’s disease is a premalignant condition. The disease seems to be caused by overexpression of transforming growth factor-alpha i.e., TGF-alpha (not TNF-alpha), which stimulates the EGFR pathway, resulting in increased proliferation of mucus cells/foveolar hyperplasia. This results in gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, mucus production, and hypochlorhydria. The antrum is usually spared.

questions.text: In a patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, what is the finding shown in the image given?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Putty kidney

A patient with abdominal pain with sterile pyuria and the abdominal X-ray showing homogenous ground glass-like calcification is suggestive of a putty kidney.

The putty kidney is a characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis (GUTB). It is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is always a secondary TB (reinfection or reactivation of old TB). Genitourinary TB usually presents as sterile pyuria.
Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications. Microbiological diagnosis is confirmed by at least 3 consecutive early-morning urine samples showing acid-fast bacilli using Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) stain and subsequently cultured (gold standard).

questions.text: What instrument is required for the following procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cystourethroscope

The instrument required for placing the Double J stent (DJ stent), as shown in the radiograph is a cystourethroscope
Cystourethroscopy allows for the examination and access of the bladder and urethra, which is crucial for guiding the DJ stent from the bladder into the ureter. This procedure involves inserting a flexible or rigid endoscope through the urethra and into the bladder, where the stent can be manoeuvred into the ureter.

While ureteroscopy is typically used to visualize and treat issues directly within the ureter, cystourethroscopy provides the necessary access and visualization to position the DJ stent correctly. This approach is effective for ensuring the stent is placed accurately, particularly in cases where access to the bladder is essential.

choices.text: It is due to failure of physiological hernia to reduce before 7 weeks
Topical application of silver nitrate is done

questions.text: A baby was born with a congenital defect as shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It is due to failure of physiological hernia to reduce before 7 weeks

The congenital defect showing herniation of the intestinal contents enclosed in a sac from the umbilicus is suggestive of omphalocele. It is due to the failure of the physiological hernia to reduce into the abdominal cavity before 10 weeks resulting in non-closure of the umbilical ring.

Physiological herniation of the midgut through the umbilicus occurs during the 5th week so as to accommodate the rapidly growing intestine and persists until the 10th week.

Omphalocele is seen in term babies and is usually associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of a-fetoprotein.

An omphalocele may contain the stomach, liver, and intestines. These contents are enclosed in a sac.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with abdominal pain and obstipation for 3 days. He gives a history of bull gore to the abdomen 3 days back. His X-ray is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hollow viscus perforation

The given clinical scenario involves a patient with a history of penetrating abdominal trauma and presenting symptoms of abdominal pain 
and obstipation. The erect radiograph shows air under the diaphragm which strongly points to a diagnosis of hollow viscous perforation.
Perforation of the alimentary tract is a life-threatening condition. This leads to the leakage of the enteric contents, thereby leading to acute bacterial peritonitis. Peritonitis is the generalized or localized inflammation of the peritoneum either due to the free spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.
